title: Monday, 29th July 2019

Cotton Eye Joe Bit less high profile but anything on Sanne pls? shares down 32% this am

AMALtd morning
11:14 am

But only because Deliveroo is literally worthless and running on fumes. The investment case is "here's a company in a winner-take-all sector whose competition exists on unicorn farts".

JP11:15am

Teeth smile

BE11:15am

Add in questions about management quality and you get to where we are, a shotgun marriage that is in effect a reverse-aqui-hire.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

What Takeaway dot com brings to the party is a CEO. That's about it really.

BE11:16am

Let me cut to the sellside.

BE11:16am

Barclays:

11:16 am
BE11:16am

In summary, we think this makes sense in the long term. There are relatively few synergies in the near term given little geographical overlap. There will be some from central costs but it isn’t a huge number in context – maybe €20m run rate savings or so. But Just Eat shareholders would be getting the best operator in the space to run the business – a notable shift from missed execution from management in the last few years (the value of this is hard to quantify). And it highlights that there is value in the Just Eat share on a SOTP basis – we think a 15% premium is OK (though dependent on what the Q2 results show on Wed). The picture for Takeaway.com is a more nuanced. On the one hand, Takeaway.com shareholders are getting exposed to a much messier story from a competitive and execution perspective in Just Eat than what they own today in Takeaway.com, whilst there would also be some risk in platform integration and management bandwidth. But we think they are compensated in two ways. 1) Just Eat shares are still quite cheap – bulls on Brazil and Canada could argue they are contributing well over a third of the JE market cap at bid price, which means Takeaway.com holders are getting access to the rest of the portfolio at a relatively cheap underlying value (still as low as low double digit EBITDA depending on the value one puts on Brazil and Canada). 2) We are believers in the value of being a global player increasing in time, with more cash flow to fight off rising competition and tech platform synergies getting more and more relevant. This is a unique opportunity to build scale and that should benefit both parties in the LT.

BE11:17am

Ta.

Dec69 - Skeptic Reminds me of the Majestic deal with Naked Wines.
BE11:17am

We are believers in there being value to being a global platform long term. We actually think the party that articulates platform value best is Naspers – their strong view has been there are tech platform benefits that will develop increasingly in time within global food delivery, particularly as own delivery (which is complex operationally) and personalization (aided by machine learning) become more important. Takeaway.com has always run one global platform and has a strong track record of integrating acquired assets onto this – the Delivery Hero Germany transaction is the most recent example of this. So in the LT, we can see why leveraging a global platform into more markets makes sense. It is also probably fair to say that Just Eat’s tech has been underinvested in over the last few years (that is changing more latterly). As competitive intensity continue to heat up globally, we also think there is value that comes from scale with more cash flow to invest against local competitors. So in time, we are firm believers that this transaction would allow both the Just Eat and Takeaway.com assets to be run better – which should create value in the LT.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

We are surprised no role for Naspers here. Naspers is indirectly a shareholder in Takeaway.com via Delivery Hero’s stake. It also owns a majority stake in iFood in Brazil (in which Just Eat owns 33%). So it has a clear vested interest here – as we see it this could have been a unique opportunity for Naspers. We are bit surprised it hasn’t found a way to get involved in this transaction as it looks to consolidate food delivery globally.

· What about Uber? We aren’t surprised the article refers to Uber Eats as being an interested party – UK, France, Australia and Canada are all big markets for Uber Eats so Just Eat has clear strategic rationale for Uber and there are more synergies near term than a deal with Takeaway.com in the near term. But of course it is perfectly possible that Uber gets involved down the line - it is possible that Takeaway.com could decide that markets like Australia and Canada are non-core within Just Eat and looks to sell those down the road.

JP11:18am

Peel Hunt:

Punter Would be interested in any light shed on the other Just down on a trading update to 46p, one broker was saying embedded value was c£3 end 2018, not an easy biz to assess. A binary situation?
JP11:19am

Others. Naspers has interests in the space, including ifood, Swiggy and Delivery Hero, and took part in a $400m investment in ifood. Given Softbank’s investments in the region, Naspers may have an incentive, but so would Softbank. Delivery Hero sold its German operations to Takeaway and its UK operations to Just Eat, as well as exiting Australia, France, Italy and the Netherlands. Finally, Uber or Deliveroo. Both are delivery-first models, both cause stress in the Just Eat camp, both are entering the marketplace model, and both provide similar, and extra, value-add services for their restaurants. It would go against Uber’s core thesis of logistics, but would bring a swathe of takeaways as well as incremental users.

11:19 am
JP11:19am

A reminder of the thesis. Just Eat was a pure-play, high margin takeaway platform, focusing on restaurants that do their own delivery, but it is now investing in its own delivery as competition takes its toll. Uber will dominate the smartphone real estate, as its Taxi app will accelerate the distribution of its Eats app. It can also take advantage of a fast-growing, captive audience inside the taxis themselves by making timely suggestions. Moreover, as Uber opens its platforms to restaurants that do their own delivery, its margins will improve, while Just Eat’s diminish as it does the opposite.

JP11:19am

Don't really buy Uber being a real competitor in the long-term, but there we go.

Frances Anything on Hammerson? Thanks!
Dec69 - Skeptic @jp. You must be over 30. Ref: Uber Eats

ha.

Tom Dalgleish Eat share as of now
Tom Dalgleish He didnt comment whether overall market had grown but he had lost long term customers
BE11:22am

What could the opportunity be worth? Clearly, its early stage but we calculate a circa £11bn valuation (£8.9bn now) for the new entity given that it is likely see at least a +52% EBITDA CAGR the next two years (as highlighted we see no meaningful rev/cost synergies in addition to the obvious cost synergies like headquarters/ combining tech teams and faster growth for JE under new management). We think this growth profile would justify a 50x 2019E EV/EBITDA multiple (given internet peers) and result in a combined valuation of greater than £10bn – with the vast majority of value creation for Just EAT. We await further updates on deal structure/ synergies etc in the next few days from the companies but with c.100% cash conversion of EBITDA, balance sheets at ~ net cash for both and assuming a takeout at 800p, we would see high double-digit FCF accretion of the deal.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

50x 2019E EV/EBITDA. Good lord.

JP11:23am

I just laughed out loud in the office.

JP11:23am

I mean, it's not Beyond Meat. But still.

Tom Dalgleish Could an Ubereats driver also moonlight for Menulog?
11:24 am
BE11:24am

And Olivetree on the counter angle.

BE11:24am

There will likely be much focus on the concept that a third party might look to compete for Just Eat. In the last few years alone there has been a raft of consolidation in this space (Amazon Deliveroo, Takeaway Delivery Hero Germany, Just Eat Hungry House) and it would be expected that a number of the large players would look at an asset like Just Eat. It was only May 2019 that Amazon was the largest investor in Deliveroo’s latest fund raising round. It is entirely likely that all the mid-level players (Just Eat, Delivery Hero. Takeaway.com) are all potential targets for much larger players. For example, Naspers, which is in the middle of rationalising its own portfolio and will be cash-rich for acquisitions, said only recently that they see the food delivery space as incredibly attractive- as 22% holders of Delivery Hero (DHER GY EUR8bn) they are potential consolidators here too. Naspers first bought a 10% stake in DHER in May 2017 and then increased this further in September of that year. Expect to see the market focus on the possible interest of Uber / Deliveroo (Amazon) and Naspers amongst others. Uber is likely to be the main name linked here, although it has broadly been focused on organically rolling out its food delivery business. Differeing to Takeaway, it would have terrific synergies with Just Eat in almost all geogrpahies which JE operates in – and with Just Eat shares trading so cheaply, it wouldn’t be at all hard to make this a very value creative transaction for Uber shareholders. However, with Just Eat nearly 50% exposed to UK markets, the CMA’s interest in Amazon’s investment in Deliveroo could highlight a potential impediment for such a deal.

BE11:25am

That is a valid point. CMA's been uncharacteristically active in the food delivery sector.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Anyway, that's deal #1. Onto deal #2?

Let me get some valuation work here.

11:28 am
JP11:29am

(@1966AndAllThat -- cheers!)

Dec69 - Skeptic @1966 I missed it sadly.
BE11:29am

Morgan Stanley with a brick of summary.

BE11:29am

On 27th July LSE confirmed it is in talks to buy Refinitiv, financial data and infrastructure provider, for ~$27bn to be funded by a share issue, leaving Refinitiv shareholders (55% owned by Blackstone, 45% Thomson Reuters) with ~37% of the combined company (but less than 30% of voting rights). The price implies 11.7x Q1 19 annualised EBITDA. Refinitiv's net debt stands at $12.2bn, so LSE would have to issue ~$14.8bn or ~£11.8bn of equity to finance the deal. In the statement, the company details £350m of run-rate cost synergies (9% of Refinitiv's 2018 costs ex D&A or 8% of combined opex) in 5 years after completion and 'strong' adjusted EPS accretion in the first full year after completion. Talks are advanced on board membership and governance. LSE's Chairman Don Robert, CEO David Schwimmer and CFO David Warren are expected to continue in their roles and discussions around lock-up provisions are on-going with Refinitiv shareholders who intend to be long-term shareholders. The terms of any transaction remain subject to LSEG Board approval and there can be no certainty that a transaction will be forthcoming. Any transaction would be conditional, inter alia, upon the approval of LSEG shareholders and antitrust and regulatory clearances, as well as other customary conditions.Financial impact: LSE indicates that it expects the deal to be earnings accretive from the first full year of completion (we assume it would be from 2020). At 26th July closing share price less 5% discount, we estimate that the group would need to issue 219m shares or 60% of current market cap to fund the deal. Based on 2018 financials, Refinitiv generated $6.3bn of revenues $1.6bn of EBITDA. This compares to LSE reported revenue of £2.1bn ($2.7bn), EBITDA £1bn ($1.3bn) - implying a combined group with ~$9bn/£7bn in revenues. Cost synergies of £350m to be delivered by year 5 equate to 9% of target OPEX and 8% of combined OPEX. Treatment of D&A would be key to earnings accretion given is it material at refinitive ($479m at Q1 19, $1916m annualised). Including depreciation but excluding amortization costs we estimate ~30% of potential EPS accretion (1). What is Refinitiv? Refinitiv was carved out of Thomson Reuters in October 2018 with a majority stake sold to a PE consortium led by Blackstone (55%) while Thomson Reuters retained the remaining 45% stake. It is a global financial data and market infrastructure provider with 40,000 customers across 190 countries. The Data platform provides real-time market data, Reuters news, analytics and risk management tools. Refintiv also has a trading business with platforms including FXAll and Matching as well as a majority stake in Tradeweb. Post transaction with Blackstone, Refinitiv embarked on a cost cutting program with $650m target savings by 2020. $350m has already been achieved at Q1 19 and two-thirds of target expected by end 2019.Strategic rationale to expand data business and diversify trading capabilities: LSE Group has focused on two principle sources of structural growth in recent years - (1) post trade risk mitigation (per LCH deal) (2) data analytics/index (per FTSE Russell deals) and it is these areas that have driven double digit top line and above sector earnings growth. The Refinitiv deal would clearly fall into the latter category and would meaningfully increase exposure to the key growth area of data analytics among others .

Irish HF guy Thompson Reuters $12bn + stake in merged entity if deal goes ahead, but they missed out on tradeweb IPO
11:30 am
BE11:30am

And Berenberg with something more paragraph-y.

Dec69 - Skeptic How did Murphy & McCrum do? @1966
BE11:30am

How much is LSE paying? We estimate that LSE will be paying 10.6x EV/EBITDA (2019E) for Refinitiv. This would appear attractive against the current average EV/EBITDA of 20.7x for listed information services companies and 14.4x for the global exchanges.
● What is the earnings impact? Management expects that any deal will be earnings-accretive in its first year. Accounting, financing and timing issues create significant uncertainty as to the precise level of earnings accretion LSE shareholders can expect. Our preliminary estimate is that 2020 EPS would rise by 35%, but we caution this could change materially with additional disclosure/clarification.
● What is the strategic rationale? This proposed deal reflects the way that electronification of trading has blurred the boundaries between exchanges and information service companies. It would significantly broaden and deepen LSE’s data and analytics offering across asset classes, geographies and customers. LSE would also gain control of three of the largest OTC trading platforms (Tradeweb, FXAll and Matching), which we view as complementary to LSE’s current strength in OTC clearing.

Irish HF guy except they do own 45% of the Refinitive stake of 50% + in tradeweb
JP11:31am

Here's UBS:

11:31 am
JP11:31am

LSE confirmed it is in talks to acquire Refinitiv for an EV of $27bnOver the weekend, LSE confirmed it is discussing a potential acquisition of Refinitiv (55% owned by Blackstone-run PE funds and 45% by Thomson Reuters). Under the discussed terms, LSE would acquire Refinitiv for a total EV of ~$27bn (£22bn) o/w $11.8bn (£9.5bn) net debt. LSE to finance the equity value through share issuance, with Refinitiv expected to own a ~37% stake in combined entity (but under 30% of the total voting rights) and remain long-term shareholders of the combined Group.

JP11:32am

Deal at 13.1x EV/Adj EBITDA; LSE Expects Strong Adj EPS Accretion in Yr1Deal is priced at 13.1x EV/EBITDA (ex- TradeWeb, 9.2x EX/EBITDA). If completed, LSE expects the deal to be strongly accretive in year one. LSE expects over £350mn of annualised cost synergies 5 years after completion. This equals 16% of Refinitiv 2018 cost base (or 33% of its 2017 cost base including $650mn of targeted cost savings from Blackstone). LSE may also benefit from lower financing costs on the legacy Refinitiv debt. We estimate the deal would take LSE's debt-to-EBITDA leverage to ~3.5x. Based on our merger model (see Figure 1), we estimate the deal would be 8% accretive for LSE in Year 1 & 20% accretive in Year 3, excluding any refinancing benefits.

JP11:32am

Expansion into Data, Trading Platforms, Analytics & DistributionA Refinitiv acquisition would pivot LSE's business model (which had been focused on Index, Clearing and Capital Markets) towards data. This is not the first time LSE has entered a new market through M&A (e.g., LCH & Russell acquisitions in 2013-14, both of which were successful deals). Refinitiv offers data (including distribution through Eikon), FX & Fixed income trading platforms (e.g., TradeWeb, FXall, Matching) and portfolio analytics/risk management solutions. Subscription revenues accounted for just 77-80% of Refinitiv's revenues over 2017-18. Refinitiv's regional revenue split has been about 40/40/20 for N America/EMEA/Asia Pac over the past 2 years.Valuation: We Rate LSE Neutral with 5,550p Price TargetAt 26x 2020 UBSe earnings, we view LSE as fairly valued. We would expect the shares to respond positively to the news.

What are the chances of a rival bidder? LSE has been the target of a bid approach once every two-and-a-half years on average since it listed in 2000. Given the strong strategic positioning of the group’s core assets (LCH and FTSE Russell), we think there is a significant (one-in-three, maybe) probability that a bid emerges for LSE as a standalone company.
Our analysis suggests that an acquisition by ICE and CME would be 11%-
and 10%-EPS-accretive respectively (assuming a 30% premium).
● With no certainty that a formal deal will be forthcoming, or that it will clear the various regulatory and competition hurdles, we make no change to our forecasts or price target.

BE11:35am

KBW shares some of the caution re the quality of Refinitiv .....

BE11:36am

At first glance, the overall growth of Refinitiv revenues is concerning. LSE has the best organic revenue growth among the exchange operators currently, and this transaction would bring them to the low end of the group on a pro forma basis. However, there are a number of very attractive assets within Refinitiv that make sense strategically for LSE in an increasingly scarce environment for acquisition targets. LSE would have a majority stake in TW, ownership of FXall, would immediately become one of the largest players in enterprise data feeds and pricing services with Elektron (growing 5% per year), and would benefit meaningfully from cost synergies, as well as the margin expansion story at Refinitiv. Our main concerns are around Refinitiv's shrinking Desktop business, as well as an extensive competition review.

BE11:40am

This is a large, transformative deal for LSE, which will likely significantly lower its
organic revenue growth rate. We believe this will cause some rather significant multiple compression, and
raises the potential for shareholder turnover. Just to give some additional detail, we estimate LSE’s standalone
organic revenue growth rate at 6.8% in 2021, which is the highest among the US and European exchange
operators. This transaction could take that organic revenue growth rate to just 3.3%, by our calculations
(assuming 1.5% growth at Refinitiv). Revenues at Refinitiv have been flat to down over a relatively long
period of time [since 2012], although the most recent two years have shown positive growth.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

This lackluster
growth has been due to Refinitiv’s Desktops business as well as Recoveries – both of which have been under
pressure because of shrinking user bases and headcount reductions across the large banks and elsewhere in
financial services. Also, while Blackstone and Thomson Reuters will likely be subject to lock-ups on their
equity, their ownership also poses some liquidity risk over the medium-term.

Irish HF guy @Excel, easy, the direct costs of sale are decided early on in a company history and the gross margin is very easy to manipulate, hence direct costs of sales are just that, all other IT, Marketing, general & admin are operating costs. Mind you if they are now delivering, that should start to come down. Gross margin is one of the accounting tricks, you want as big a number as possible, especially when you actually do not make any money or not much

Implications for the broader Industry: If the reported deal takes place, it would reaffirm our stance on a difficult Gx environment, in which manufacturers are feelingincreasingpressure fromlarger purchasing consortiaas well as intense competition amongst Gx manufacturers (esp from India).We cite tworecent eventssuggesting continued fundamental headwinds:1) AMRX’s~30% FY19 EBITDA cutearlier this month(Guidance Cut Supports Our Stance on Generics, 7/11)and 2) Continued mid-teens declines in Sandoz’s U.S. base business.This announcement proposes an idea that perhaps strategicmergersare one tactic to combat industry pressures, aslarger, more cohesive entitiesarelikely better suited to deal with ongoingstructural disadvantagesin the Gx space.

BE11:48am

The reported planned JV between Pfizer Upjohn and Mylan comes as
little surprise given PFE’s long-standing aspirations and recent corporate activity
around divesting its non-innovative pharma businesses. The reported transaction in
the WSJ follows Pfizer’s recent consumer JV and HIV joint ventures with third
parties, and their 2013 spin of Zoetis, Pfizer’s former animal health division. A taxfree
spin through a Reverse Morris Trust seems like the most likely structure
compared with the previous JV type structures used with PFE consumer and HIV
businesses. PFE shareholders stand to benefit through: (i) acceleration in parent
Pfizer 5YR EBITDA CAGR post distribution of PFE’s shares in NewCo by c.150bp;
(ii) deleveraging of Pfizer balance sheet; (iii) enhancement in value of PFE’s
consumer sub though revenue and cost synergies. PFE investor attention will likely
quickly turn to cash distribution and heightened probability of further material M&A
given strengthened balance sheet. MRK is our only Buy-rated US Major. We prefer
Buy-rated AZN, Sanofi, Novartis and Bayer in EU.

BE11:50am

What’s next for PFE? Given recent industry consolidation in pharma (Takeda/
Shire, AbbVie/ Allergan and others), investor focus will shift to PFE’s balance sheet,
both in terms of distribution of shares in NewCo and/or increased probability of M&A
given PFE’s bolstered B/S (anticipated 2020E net debt/ EBITDA less than 1x post receipt of
$12bn cash from NewCo). We continue to be doubtful of future large-scale M&A
with other pharma majors given strategic intent of peers and barriers to hostile M&A
in EU. Greater opportunities exist within larger biotechs. We note PFE’s recent
historic position eschewing large-scale acquisitions in favor of bolt-on consistent
with the recent Array acquisition (see Pfizer, Apr 18). Potential routes for distribution
of proceeds for PFE’s 60% share in NewCo include pro-rate share distribution,
exchange or less likely, equity offering.

11:50 am
BE11:51am

What’s next for MYL? Based on our calculations (see below), we see potential
near-term upside to Mylan’s share price, though we note that this is dependent on
the multiple the market ascribes to the newly-formed combined entity. A more
diverse portfolio for NewCo (products + geographies, particularly increased
exposure to ex-US markets) should drive near-term upside vs. Mylan’s current
valuation, we believe, though we acknowledge that the uncertainty surrounding the
potential impact of the unresolved FTC price collusion litigation is likely to persist.

BE12:00pm

Brand pressure from key suppliers. Sports Direct's elevation strategy is designed to make its stores more appealing to customers and to secure more premium product from the big third party brands eg Nike and adidas. However in its statement SPD notes that it does not receive access to premium product as quickly as the stores deserve, plus its competition is getting stronger. As such we see higher than average inventory risk for SPD and expect its inventory provisioning to be volatile, which has been an issue in the past for the company.

BE12:01pm

Results delayed due to Belgian tax payment notice. SPD's results were delayed on Friday due to it receiving a payment notice from the Belgian tax authorities for EUR674mn, relating to the tax treatment of goods being moved intra-Group throughout the EU via Belgium. SPD only has 35 stores in Belgium and it believes that "it is less than probable that material VAT and penalties will be due in Belgium as a result of the tax audit." However at the very least we think this does raise concerns about the provision of timely and accurate documentation to tax authorities.

BE12:02pm

Cautious outlook given structural pressures on department stores and USD sourcing headwinds. SPD's FY19 revenue was broadly in line with our estimate, underlying EBITDA 3% was below our estimate and net debt was slightly higher than expected. SPD has chosen not to give FY20 guidance, which we think partly relates to uncertainty as to the outlook for the store estate and profitability of House of Fraser. As we highlighted in our October 2018 report "Remain cautious post House of Fraser acquisition..." we think department stores will continue to face a number of structural pressures. This has contributed to us reducing our underlying EBITDA forecasts by 6-10%, as we now don't expect any meaningful underlying improvement for HoF until FY21 at the earliest. In addition SPD faces USD sourcing headwinds given it will be coming off a FY20 £/GBP hedging rate of 1.42. This increases the risk of volume or gross margin pressure from FY21 onwards.

BE12:03pm

Friday’s delays and general nonsense weren’t ‘Just Mike’ or maverick or slapstick, they were an exasperating and rude means of avoiding wide analytical questioning on the very disappointing FY19. It wasn’t a shocker of a year in some numeric respects, and the revelation that HOF was a mistake was obviously in the post, but the home truths about the core Sports Direct business were pretty shocking and management seems to be out of ideas. The elevation programme isn’t currying favour with brands and the shopper has moved away from the core SD. This is far more important than any tabloid headlines the chief executive may garner, and probably more share price relevant than the Belgian tax claim. Retail moves at pace: sports retail has been no different, and Sports Direct has been skinned.

BE12:04pm

Serious problems at the core. The company didn’t engage with analysts before the FD left and have openly admitted that they won’t engage now either. So it’s best to concentrate on the big picture rather than the minutiae of the numbers. The two sections that were of most note within the stream of consciousness that was the Prelims discussed the elevation programme and the relationships with the major brands. Neither are going well, and this doesn’t come as a big surprise to us. We have always thought that the ‘Elevated’ stores looked great, but couldn’t believe that the big manufacturers would think they were an accurate representation of the rest of the chain. Therefore, whilst SD may have done all the likes of Nike and adidas asked them to do in the flagship stores, the premium product that maybe it was expecting as a consequence has not emerged. And it doesn’t sound like that is about to change: we weren’t at the analysts meeting, so we’re talking second hand, but it sounds like management said something along the lines of ‘the big brands have got JD and Foot Locker so why do they need us?’ Quite.

Irish HF guy @Tom, penneys story re rents is enough to see INTU go to near zero, what do you think?

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

So what now? The fact that the elevation programme is now struggling to generate a return as the better product isn’t coming through is highly worrying.
Should it plough on with the expensive flagships and hope that the brands have a change of heart? That doesn’t sound like the answer to us. Should it spend a
fortune upgrading all the stores? Possibly, but £600m tax bills and buying ‘terminal’ assets don’t help the financial ability to do that. The most realistic strategy to us seems to be to do the best it can with the core assets and see if it can generate enough cash to fund some growth elsewhere in the group. It’s not an enormously exciting option, but it looks the best one open to SD at the moment.
As an aside, we’d ask why the company has parted ways with the massively respected Karen Byers. There’s a blatant contradiction here: Karen apparently left because of the elevation strategy, which management openly admits hasn’t worked. We just don’t think we understand.
We are disappointed how Friday played out but it’s far more worrying that Sports Direct now seems to be strategically snookered, check-mated and clean bowled. The shares are hard to value, but are surely only for the very brave.
